A remote authenticated user can determine portions of the key stream by XORing known plaintext values with the corresponding encrypted values.  With knowledge of the target username, the remote user can generate the necessary cookie values to access the target user's account.

Citrix Access Gateway is also affected.

nnposter reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote authenticated user may be able to create cookies to gain access to arbitrary accounts on the system.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The Citrix advisory is available at:

http://support.citrix.com/article/CTX115496

Title: Citrix NetScaler Input Validation Hole in 'generic_api_call' Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Citrix NetScaler.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
The web management interface does not properly filter HTML code from user-supplied input before displaying the input.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser.  The code will originate from the Citrix NetScaler device and will run in the security context of that device.  As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the device, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the device, or take actions on the device acting as the target user.

The '/ws/generic_api_call.pl' script is affected.

A demonstration exploit URL is provided:

http://[target]/ws/generic_api_call.pl?function=statns&standalone=%3c/script%3e%3cscript%3ealert(document.cookie)%3c/script%3e%3cscript%3e

nnposter reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the Citrix NetScaler device, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the device, or take actions on the device acting as the target user.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: SonicWALL SSL-VPN Client Buffer Overflows in WebCacheCleaner/NeLaunchCtrl ActiveX Controls Let Remote Users Execute Arbitrary Code
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the SonicWALL SSL-VPN Client software and NetExtender devices.  A remote user can cause arbitrary code to be executed on the target user's system.
A remote user can create specially crafted HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will trigger a buffer overflow in the WebCacheCleaner ActiveX control or the NeLaunchCtrl ActiveX control and execute arbitrary code on the target system.  The code will run with the privileges of the target user.

The CLSIDs of the vulnerable controls are: 6EEFD7B1-B26C-440D-B55A-1EC677189F30 and 79D6214F-CFCE-480F-9901-27950E78F1E6

The NetExtender devices and SSL-VPN client software are affected.

The vendor was notified on May 21, 2007.

Will Dormann of CERT/CC reported one of these vulnerabilities.  lofi42 independently reported both vulnerabilities via SEC Consult.

The original advisories are available at:

http://www.kb.cert.org/vuls/id/298521
http://www.sec-consult.com/fileadmin/Advisories/20071101-0_sonicwall_multiple.txt
Impact': A remote user can create HTML that, when loaded by the target user, will execute arbitrary code on the target user's system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued fixed versions (version 2.1 of SSL-VPN 200; version 2.5 of SSL-VPN 2000/4000).

The vendor has not provided a publicly available advisory.

Title: Nortel VPN Router Lets Remote Users Access VPNs and Administrative Functions
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Nortel VPN Router.  A remote user can access the target system.
The LDAP template included with router builds 3_60 and later includes two default user accounts (FIPSecryptedtest1219 and FIPSunecryptedtest1219) for diagnostic purposes.  A remote user can use one of these accounts to access the VPN.

A remote user can supply a specially crafted URL to access some administrator functions via the web administration interface without authenticating.  The user can then modify certain configuration settings.

Detack GmbH discovered these vulnerabilities.
Impact':
A remote user can access the target VPN.

A remote user can gain partial administrative access.
Solution:
The vendor has issued fixed versions (5_05.149, 5_05.304, and 6_05.140).

The Nortel advisory (Bulletin 2007007918) is available at:

http://www.nortel.com/securityadvisories

Title: Citrix Access Gateway LDAP Authentication Flaw Grants Access to Remote Users
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Citrix Access Gateway.  A remote user can gain access in certain cases.
If the Advanced Access Control (AAC) option of the target Access Gateway is configured to use LDAP authentication, then a remote user can login without supplying valid authentication credentials.

Only AAC version 4.2 using LDAP authentication is affected.
Impact': A remote user can gain access to the ostensibly protected network or application.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a hot fix (AAC420W004).

The Citrix advisory is available at:

http://support.citrix.com/article/CTX110950

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator Lets Remote Users Access Certain FTP Commands
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator in the FTP file management function.  A remote user can execute certain FTP commands.
If the device is configured to use the FTP protocol to manage files stored on the concentrator, a remote user can execute the CWD, MKD, CDUP, RNFR, SIZE, and RMD FTP commands.  This allows certain files on the system to be deleted or renamed.  For example, the configuration could be changed to a different (existing) configuration file.

None of these vulnerabilities can be exploited to upload or download files.

Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug IDs CSCse10733 and CSCse10753 to these vulnerabilities.

Cisco VPN 3000 series concentrator models 3005, 3015, 3020, 3030, 3060, and 3080 are affected.

The Cisco VPN 3002 Hardware Client is not affected.

Cisco credits the NCC Group with reporting these vulnerabilities.
Impact': A remote user can rename or delete certain files on the target system.
Solution:
The vendor has issued the following fixed versions:  4.1(7)M and 4.7(2)G

The Cisco advisory is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20060823-vpn3k.shtml

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator IKE v1 Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a high rate of Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Phase-1 requests to prevent valid clients from connecting or re-keying.

The target concentrator may be affected by packets sent at a rate of 2 packets per second and becomes unusable when packets are sent at a rate of 10 packets per second.  The attack does not require high bandwidth.

One the packet flood stops, the target device will return to normal operations.

The attack does not affect existing VPN tunnels (unless the tunnel needs to rekey).

Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug IDs CSCse70811, CSCdt92467, and CSCsb51032 to this vulnerability.

The vendor was notified on July 4, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nta-monitor.com/posts/2006/07/cisco-concentrator-dos.html

Roy Hills from NTA Monitor reported this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Cisco notes that this vulnerability is inherent in the IKE version 1 protocol and is not specific to any vendor implementation.  Other Cisco products that use this version of the protocol are the PIX and ASA security appliances and Cisco IOS software.  On Cisco IOS, the vulnerability can be mitigated using the "Call Admission Control for IKE" feature:

http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/sw/iosswrel/ps5207/products_feature_guide09186a0080229125.html

The Cisco response is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sr-20060726-ike.shtml

Title: nCipher Hardware Security Module May Let Local Users Determine Diffie-Hellman Keys
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in nCipher's Hardware Security Module.  A local user may be able to determine Diffie-Hellman keys in certain situations.
In some situations, the Hardware Security Module may generate Diffie-Hellman keys that are less secure than intended.  A local user can conduct and expensive but possible attack to recover the private key.
Impact': A local user may be able to determine Diffie-Hellman keys.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.  After upgrading, affected keys should be replaced.

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.ncipher.com/support/advisories/keysigs/advis12.txt.asc

Title: (Juniper Issues Fix for IVE) OpenSSL SSL_OP_MSIE_SSLV2_RSA_PADDING Option May Let Remote Users Rollback the Protocol Version
Version(s): IVE versions up to and including 4.2R6, 5.0R5 and 5.1R3
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in OpenSSL.  A remote user may be able to cause a target client and server to rollback to a weaker cryptographic protocol in certain cases.  Juniper (Netscreen) IVE is affected.
The SSL_OP_MSIE_SSLV2_RSA_PADDING option (or SSL_OP_ALL option) disables a verification step in the SSL 2.0 server that would otherwise prevent active protocol-version rollback attacks.

A remote user can conduct a "man in the middle" attack to force a client and a server to negotiate the SSL 2.0 protocol instead of SSL 3.0 or TLS 1.0.  The SSL 2.0 protocol is a cryptographically weak protocol.

Applications that use the OpenSSL SSL/TLS server implementation may be affected.

Applications that do not use SSL_OP_MSIE_SSLV2_RSA_PADDING and SSL_OP_ALL are not affected.  Applications that disable the use of SSL 2.0 are also not affected.

The vendor credits Yutaka Oiwa of the Research Center for Information Security, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (AIST), Japan, with reporting this vulnerability.
Impact': A remote user with the ability to conduct a man-in-the-middle attack can cause a client and server to use the weaker SSL 2.0 protocol.
Solution:
Juniper has issued a fix for Netscreen IVE, which is affected by this OpenSSL vulnerability.  The following fixed versions are available:

    * 4.2R7
    * 5.0R6
    * 5.1R4

The fix disables SSL 2.0 compatibility and may break compatibility with IE 3.02 and prior versions.

The Juniper advisory is available at:

http://www.juniper.net/support/security/alerts/PSN-2005-12-025.txt

Title: Symantec Firewall/VPN Appliance IPSec IKE Processing Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Symantec Firewall/VPN Appliance.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The device does not properly validate Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets.  A remote user can send specially crafted ISAKMP packets to trigger a buffer overflow and cause the ISAKMP daemon to crash.  This will cause the dynamic VPN services to become unavailable.

A test suite developed by the University of Oulu Secure Programming Group (OUSPG) was used to discover these vulnerabilities.
Impact': A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a patch (Build 1.8F), available at:

http://www.symantec.com/techsupp/enterprise/select_product_updates.html

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://securityresponse.symantec.com/avcenter/security/Content/2005.11.21.html

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 IPSec IKE Processing Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Cisco VPN 3000 in the processing of IPSec Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
The University of Oulu Secure Programming Group (OUSPG) "PROTOS" Test Suite for IPSec can be used to cause denial of service conditions on several Cisco products.

A remote user can send certain specially crafted packets to cause the target device to reset.  This can be done repeatedly to cause prolonged denial of service conditions.

Cisco has assigned Cisco bug ID CSCsb15296 to this vulnerability.

The original advisory from CERT-FI and NISCC is available at:

http://www.niscc.gov.uk/niscc/docs/re-20051114-01014.pdf?lang=en
Impact': A remote user can cause the target device to reset.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix (4.1(7)H, 4.7(2)B).

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sa-20051114-ipsec.shtml

Title: Juniper NetScreen ScreenOS Lets Remote Users Determine Valid VPN Usernames
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in Juniper NetScreen VPN products.  A remote user can determine valid usernames on the target device.
When remote access VPNs are configured for IKE with pre-shared key authentication, a remote user can perform a brute force guessing attack to determine valid VPN usernames on the target device.  This occurs because the system responds differently to valid usernames than it does to invalid usernames.  A remote user can send an IKE Aggressive Mode packet with the specified username.  If the username is valid, the target system will respond.  If the username is invalid, the system will not respond.

IKE Main Mode is not affected.  Certificate authentication is not affected.

With knowledge of a valid username, the remote user can then obtain a hash value from the device.

If the VPN is configured to use XAUTH is used as a second-level of authentication, the remote user may be able to conduct a man-in-the-middle attack against the XAUTH user authentication mechanism.

The vendor was notified on June 21, 2005.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nta-monitor.com/news/vpn-flaws/juniper/netscreen/index.htm
Impact': A remote user can determine valid usernames on the target device.
Solution:
The vendor has issued an advisory, available at:

http://www.juniper.net/support/security/alerts/adv5212.txt

The advisory provides two options to address this vulnerability.  The first option involves following better security practices in selecting usernames and keys.  The second option is to use IKE Main Mode with Certificates issued by a certificate authority instead of using IKE Aggressive Mode with pre-shared keys.

Title: (Cisco Issues Revised Fix) Cisco VPN 3000 Lets Remote Users Determine Valid Groupnames
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco VPN 3000 concentrators.  A remote user can determine valid groupnames.
When groupname authentication is used, the system provides a different response to a connection request with a valid groupname than it does with an invalid groupname.  A remote user can connect to the target system repeatedly and send an IKE Aggressive Mode packet using different groupnames to attempt to determine valid groupnames.  The system will respond only to packets with a valid groupname.

Site-to-site VPNs and remote access VPNs using certificate authentication are not affected.

Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCeg00323 ("vpn3k - inconsistent behavior on scanning") and CSCsb38075 to this vulnerability.

The vendor was notified on September 20, 2004.

Roy Hills from NTA Monitor reported this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nta-monitor.com/news/vpn-flaws/cisco/VPN-Concentrator/index.htm
Impact': A remote user can determine valid groupnames on the target device.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.1.7.G).

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sn-20050624-vpn-grpname.shtml

[Editor's note: Cisco originally reported that the fix was included in 4.1.7.F but issued an update to their advisory on April 19, 2006 indicating that the first version containing the fix is 4.1.7.G.]

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Lets Remote Users Determine Valid Groupnames
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco VPN 3000 concentrators.  A remote user can determine valid groupnames.
When groupname authentication is used, the system provides a different response to a connection request with a valid groupname than it does with an invalid groupname.  A remote user can connect to the target system repeatedly and send an IKE Aggressive Mode packet using different groupnames to attempt to determine valid groupnames.  The system will respond only to packets with a valid groupname.

Site-to-site VPNs and remote access VPNs using certificate authentication are not affected.

Cisco has assigned Cisco Bug ID CSCeg00323 ("vpn3k - inconsistent behavior on scanning") and CSCsb38075 to this vulnerability.

The vendor was notified on September 20, 2004.

Roy Hills from NTA Monitor reported this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nta-monitor.com/news/vpn-flaws/cisco/VPN-Concentrator/index.htm
Impact': A remote user can determine valid groupnames on the target device.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fixed version (4.1.7.G).

The vendor's advisory is available at:

http://www.cisco.com/warp/public/707/cisco-sn-20050624-vpn-grpname.shtml

[Editor's note: Cisco originally reported that the fix was included in 4.1.7.F but issued an update to their advisory on April 19, 2006 indicating that the first version containing the fix is 4.1.7.G.]

Title: Nortel VPN Router Lets Remote Users Deny Service
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Nortel VPN Router.  A remote user can cause denial of service conditions.
A remote user can send a single IKE packet with a specially crafted ISAKMP header to the target device to cause the device to crash. In some cases, the router will reboot.  In other cases, a manual restart is required to return the system to normal operations.

The vendor credits Roy Hills, Technical Director of NTA-Monitor, with reporting this vulnerability.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.nta-monitor.com/news/vpn-flaws/nortel/vpn-router-dos/

The vendor was notified on March 3, 2005.

[Editor's note:  The VPN Router was formerly know as the Contivity router.]
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to crash.  A manual restart may be required to return the system to normal operations.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fixed version (5.05.202).  This fix replaces the previously issued 5.05.200 fix, which contained a flaw.

The vendor has also issued the following additional fixes:

Current Version, Patched Version
4.06.225, 4.06.226
4.75.184, 4.75.185
4.76.165, 4.76.166
4.85.206, 4.85.208
4.90.315, 4.90.316
5.00.302, 5.00.303

Title: Juniper NetScreen IVE Lets Remote Users Conduct Brute-Force Password Guessing Attacks
Description:
GoSecure reported a vulnerability in the Juniper NetScreen (Neoteris) IVE in 'changepassword.cgi'.  A remote user can conduct unlimited brute-force password guessing attempts.
When a user's password expires and the user subsequently attempts to authenticate to the system, the user is presented with the 'changepassword.cgi' script without having to authenticate.  This script allows the user to attempt to login with the expired password without limiting the number of authentication attempts.  As a result, a remote user with knowledge of a valid user account that has an expired password can conduct a brute force password guessting attack.

Only systems that are configured with an LDAP or NT domain authentication server are affected.

The original advisory is available at:

http://www.gosecure.ca/SecInfo/gosecure-2004-10.txt
Impact': A remote user can conduct brute-force password guessing attacks.
Solution:
The vendor has issued a fix.

More information is available to registered customers at:

http://www.juniper.net/alerts/viewalert.jsp?actionBtn=Seach&txtAlertNumber=PSN-2004-08-25&viewMode=view

Title: Symantec Clientless VPN Gateway 4400 Lets Remote Authentication Users Modify Other User Credentials
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Symantec Clientless VPN Gateway 4400 Series.  A remote authenticated user can modify another user's authentication information.
Symantec reported that there are "various security vulnerabilities" in the ActiveX file browser and the HTML file browser.  No further details were provided.

It is also reported that the end user user-interface (UI) contains cross-site scripting flaws.

It is also reported that the end user UI allows a remote authenticated user to change a target user's single signon information, including the username and password.
Impact':
A remote authenticated user can change a target user's single signon information, including the username and password.

A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the VPN Gateway, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

The impact of several of the vulnerabilities was not disclosed.
Solution:
The vendor has released a fix (Hotfix SCVG5-20040806-00), described at:

ftp://ftp.symantec.com/public/english_us_canada/products/sym_clientless_vpn/sym_clientless_vpn_5/updates/hf3-readme.txt

Title: Symantec Gateway Security 360R May Let Remote Wireless Users Bypass the Security Access Controls
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Symantec Gateway Security 360R.  A remote user on the wireless interface can send certain packets through to the internal network when the system is configured to not allow those packets.
Dev Null reported that a remote user can send non-VPN packets via the wireless interface to the internal LAN even if the "Enforce VPN Tunnels/Disallow IPSec pass thru" and "Enforce VPN Tunnels/Allow IPSec pass thru" settings are configured.

The documentation reportedly states that these settings only permit DNS, DHCP, and ARP traffic to pass to the internal network (along with VPN traffic).  However, the report indicates that it is possible to send HTTP, ODBC, and other traffic to the internal network.

The behavior occurs whether or not WEP is being used, the report said.

The vendor has reportedly been notified.
Impact': A remote user on the wireless interface may be able to bypass the security access controls and connect to the internal network.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco IPsec Implementation Lets Certain Users Conduct Man-in-the-Middle Attacks
Description:
An authentication vulnerability was reported in Cisco IPsec VPN products, including the VPN 3000 concentrator.  A user with access to Group Passwords can conduct man-in-the-middle attacks to hijack user sessions or masquerade as a VPN server.
Cisco issued a Security Notice (Document ID: 50600) confirming a previously reported group password vulnerability in Cisco's IPSec VPN implementation.

Cisco reports that some demonstration exploit code is available.

Cisco confirmed that a remote user can conduct a Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack to emulate a VPN head end server and steal valid user names and passwords or hijack connections using a previously recovered Group Password.  If Group Passwords are used as the pre-shared key during Internet Key Exchange (IKE) Phase 1 in the XAUTH protocol, the system is vulnerable, because the user name and password in XAUTH transmitted over the network are encrypted only by the Phase 1 IKE security association (SA), which is derived from the Group Password in this case.

A remote user with possession of the Group Passwords can hijack a target user's connection or masquerade as a VPN head end to steal user names and passwords.
Impact': A remote user with possession of the Group Passwords can hijack a target user's connection or masquerade as a VPN server to obtain user names and passwords.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.  Cisco recommends that customers deploy Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) and carefully evaluate the risks of deploying Group Password based authentication schemes.

To fix this flaw, Cisco plans to implement a hybrid IKE authentication mode for the Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator, Cisco VPN Client (software client), and Cisco VPN 3002 Hardware Client.  This feature is planned for the third quarter of the calendar year 2004.

Title: Cisco IPSec VPN Services Module IKE Bug Lets Remote Users Crash the Affected Switch/Router
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco IPSec VPN Services Module (VPNSM).  A remote user can cause the target switch or router using the VPNSM to crash and reload.
Cisco reported that the VPNSM for the Cisco Catalyst 6500 Series Switch and the Cisco 7600 Series Internet Router contains a vulnerability in the processing of Internet Key Exchange (IKE) packets.  A remote user can send a specially crafted IKE packet to the target device to trigger the flaw, the report said.

Cisco has assigned Cisco bug ID CSCed30113 to this vulnerability.

The vendor indicates that devices running Cisco IOS release train 12.1E are not affected.
Impact': A remote user can cause the device to crash and reload.
Solution:
Cisco has released fixed versions of IOS (12.2(17b)SXA, 12.2(17d)SXB, 12.2(14)SY03, and 12.2(14)ZA8).  For information, see the applicable release notes:

12.2(17b)SXA Release Notes:
       http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/sw/iosswrel/ps5014/prod_bulletin09186a00801df1dd.html

12.2(17d)SXB Release Notes:
       http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/sw/iosswrel/ps5012/prod_bulletin09186a00802078b5.html

12.2(14)SY03 Release Notes:
       http://www.cisco.com/en/US/products/sw/iosswrel/ps1835/products_tech_note09186a00801ab5a3.shtml

Title: (Symantec Issues Fix for Clientless VPN Gateway) OpenSSL  SSL/TLS Handshade Flaws May Let Remote Users Crash OpenSSL-based Applications
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in OpenSSL, primarily involving the processing of SSL/TLS protocol handshakes. A remote user can cause OpenSSL to crash.  The Symantec Clientless VPN Gateway is affected.
It is reported that there is a null-pointer assignment in the do_change_cipher_spec() function [CVE: CVE-2004-0079].  A remote user can perform a specially crafted SSL/TLS handshake with a target server to cause OpenSSL to crash on the target system.  This may cause the application using OpenSSL to crash.

All versions of OpenSSL from 0.9.6c to 0.9.6k inclusive and from 0.9.7a to 0.9.7c inclusive are reportedly vulnerable to this null-pointer bug.

It is also reported that there is a flaw in performing SSL/TLS handshakes using Kerberos ciphersuites [CVE: CVE-2004-0112].  A remote user can perform a specially crafted SSL/TLS handshake against a server that is using Kerberos ciphersuites to cause OpenSSL to crash on the target system.

OpenSSL versions 0.9.7a, 0.9.7b, and 0.9.7c are reported to be vulnerable to this Kerberos handshake bug.

It is also reported that a remote user may be able to cause OpenSSL to enter an infinite loop due to a flaw in a patch introduced in 0.9.6d [CVE: CVE-2004-0081].

The vendor credits Dr. Stephen Henson of the OpenSSL core team as well as Codenomicon for supplying their TLS Test Tool and Joe Orton of Red Hat for performing the majority of the testing.
Impact': A remote user can cause OpenSSL to crash, which may cause an application using OpenSSL to crash.  The specific impact depends on the application that uses the OpenSSL library.
Solution:
Symantec has issued a fix for the Symantec Clientless VPN Gateway 5.0 (Hotfix SCVG5-20040326-00), available at:

ftp://ftp.symantec.com/public/english_us_canada/products/sym_clientless_vpn/sym_clientless_vpn_5/updates/SCVG5-20040326-00.tgz
ftp://ftp.symantec.com/public/english_us_canada/products/sym_clientless_vpn/sym_clientless_vpn_5/updates/hf1-readme.txt

Title: (NetScreen Issues Fix for NetScreen IVE) OpenSSL  SSL/TLS Handshade Flaws May Let Remote Users Crash OpenSSL-based Applications
Description:
Some vulnerabilities were reported in OpenSSL, primarily involving the processing of SSL/TLS protocol handshakes. A remote user can cause OpenSSL to crash.  The NetScreen Instant Virtual Extranet (IVE) is affected.
It is reported that a remote user may be able to cause OpenSSL to enter an infinite loop due to a flaw in a patch introduced in OpenSSL 0.9.6d [CVE: CVE-2004-0081].  A remote user can cause NetScreen IVE to become unresponsive.

Other flaws were reported in OpenSSL but do not affect NetScreen IVE, the report said.
Impact': A remote user can cause OpenSSL to crash, which may cause an application using OpenSSL to crash.  The specific impact depends on the application that uses the OpenSSL library.
Solution:
NetScreen has released patches for all affected IVE OS versions, available to customers at:

https://support.neoteris.com

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) NetScreen-SA 5000 Input Validation Flaw in 'delhomepage.cgi' Permits Cross-Site Scripting Attacks
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the NetScreen-SA 5000 series.  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks.
It is reported that the 'delhomepage.cgi' component does not properly validate user-supplied input in the 'row' parameter.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by an authenticated target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the NetScreen-SA 5000 device and will run in the security context of that device. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the device, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the device, or take actions on the device acting as the target user. 

The vendor was reportedly notified on February 6, 2004.
Impact': A remote user can access the target user's cookies (including authentication cookies), if any, associated with the device, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the device, or take actions on the device acting as the target user.
Solution:
The vendor has released the following fixes:

- - 3.2.1 Patch 1-S2      (Build 5633)
- - 3.3-S1                (Build 5607)
- - 3.3 Patch 1-S1        (Build 5605)
- - 3.3.1-S1              (Build 5651)

The fixes are available on the NetScreen IVE support website at:

https://support.neoteris.com

The vendor notes that customers with questions can contact the NetScreen IVE Technical Assistance Center at 408-543-2991 (Option 2) or send email to help@support.neoteris.com

Title: Neoteris Instant Virtual Extranet Input Validation Flaw Lets Remote Users Hijack VPN Sessions
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
An input validation vulnerability was reported in the Neoteris Instant Virtual Extranet (IVE).  A remote user can conduct cross-site scripting attacks to hijack user sessions.
It is reported that a CGI script does not properly validate user-supplied input in one argument passed to the script.  A remote user can create a specially crafted URL that, when loaded by a target user, will cause arbitrary scripting code to be executed by the target user's browser. The code will originate from the IVE site and will run in the security context of that site. As a result, the code will be able to access the target user's cookies (including session authentication cookies), associated with the site, access data recently submitted by the target user via web form to the site, or take actions on the site acting as the target user.

The report confirms that a remote user can hijack a target user's VPN session.

The affected CGI script and script argument was not disclosed.
Impact': A remote user can create a URL that, when loaded by a target user, will allow the remote user to hijack the target user's VPN session.
Solution:
The vendor has released a patch for version 3.01 and prior.  A fix version (3.1) is also available to customers at:

https://support.neoteris.com/

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Series Concentrators May Let Remote Users Traverse The VPN Device
Description:
Several vulnerabilities were reported in the Cisco VPN 3000 series VPN concentrators, also affecting the Cisco VPN 3002 Hardware Client.  Unauthorized traffic may traverse the VPN to the private network.  A remote user can also cause the device to reload.
It is reported that, when IPSec over TCP is enabled for a port on the concentrator, TCP traffic on that port may traverse the VPN device and connect to hosts on the ostensibly protected private network [CVE: CVE-2003-0258].

It is also reported that a remote user can send a specially crafted (and malformed) SSH initialization packet to the VPN device during the initial SSH session setup to cause the device to reload [CVE: CVE-2003-0259].

Finally, a remote user can send a flood of specially crafted (and malformed) ICMP packets to the device to cause performance to degrade or to cause the device to reload [CVE: CVE-2003-0260].

Cisco reports that Models 3005, 3015, 3030, 3060, 3080 are affected.

Cisco has assigned Cisco bug ID CSCea77143 (IPSec over TCP), CSCdz15393 (SSH), and CSCdt84906 (ICMP) to these vulnerabilities.

The vendor notes that 3.1.x, 3.0.x, and 2.x.x are not affected by Cisco bug ID CSCea77143.
Impact':
A remote user can traverse the device to access hosts on the private network when the device is configured for IPSec over TCP.

A remote user can cause the device to reload or performance of the device to degrade.
Solution:
The vendor has released fixed versions (4.0.1, 3.6.7F, and later versions in those release series).

Upgrade procedures are available at:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/vpn/vpn3000/

Title: (Cisco Fixes Cisco Secure Content Accelerator) Re: OpenSSL Has Multiple Buffer Overflows That Allow Remote Users to Execute Arbitrary Code with Root Privileges
Impact: Execution of arbitrary code via network
Description:
Four buffer overflow conditions were reported in OpenSSL.  The Cisco Secure Content Accelerator is reportedly affected and may crash and reboot when an exploit is attempted.
The vendor has reported that A.L. Digital Ltd and The Bunker have uncovered multiple buffer overflows in OpenSSL, discovered during a security review.

A remote user could create a specially crafted, oversized client master key and use SSL2 to trigger an overflow on an SSL server.  According to the report, this vulnerability was independently discovered by Neohapsis, which has confirmed that the overflow can be exploited to execute arbitrary code.

A remote user with an SSL server could create a specially crafted, oversized session ID and supply this ID to a target client using SSL3 to trigger an overflow.

A remote user could supply a specially crafted, oversized master key to an SSL3 server to trigger an overflow.  It is reported that this flaw affects OpenSSL 0.9.7 prior to version 0.9.7-beta3 when Kerberos is enabled.

Several buffers used for ASCII representations of integers are reportedly too small on 64 bit platforms.

The report also states that other potential buffer overflows that are currently considered to be non-exploitable have been discovered.

The vendor notes that Adi Stav and James Yonan independently reported that the ASN1 parser can be confused by certain invalid encodings, potentially allowing a remote user to cause denial of service conditions.  An OpenSSL-based application that use the ASN1 library to parse untrusted data (including all SSL or TLS applications using S/MIME [PKCS#7] or certificate generation routines) are affected.
Impact':
A remote user may be able cause the Cisco Secure Content Accelerator to crash.

For the flaws in OpenSSL, a remote user acting as an SSL server could cause arbitrary code to be executed on an SSL client that is connecting to the server.  It is not clear if the Cisco Secure Content Accelerator allows code execution or not.
Solution:
Cisco has issued a fixed version (3.2.0.20) of the Cisco Secure Content Accelerator, available at:

http://www.cisco.com/cgi-bin/tablebuild.pl/cs-conacc

The Release-notes are available at:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/webscale/css/css_sca/sca_320/v320b20.htm#xtocid13

Title: Netgear ProSafe VPN Firewall Discloses Passwords Via Configuration Backup File
Version(s): FVS318 ProSafe VPN Firewall; firmware 1.1 and prior versions
Description:
A password disclosure vulnerability was reported in Netgear's ProSafe VPN Firewall router.  When an administrator makes a backup of the configuration, the administrative password is stored in plain text.
It is reported that the configuration backup file includes (among other data) the username for the ISP Internet connection and the password for the device's web management interface (the username for the web management interface is always 'admin').
Impact': A local user on the administrator's computer may be able to view the device's administrative password in the configuration backup file.
Solution:
No solution was available at the time of this entry.

The author of the report suggests that administrators encrypt the backup file for storage.

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator Has Multiple Bugs That Disclose Information, Allow Denial of Service, and Allow Unauthorized Packets to Pass
Description:
Cisco reported multiple vulnerabilities in their Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator device.  Information may be disclosed to remote users. A remote user can cause the device to reload or to stop processing traffic.  A certain configuration may cause the device to pass unauthorized packets through the device.
An internal authentication bug was reported.  A remote user could login via IPSec using a group account username and password of another group account on the device in a certain situation, such as when no user accounts are configured.

A remote user can submit a long HTTP GET request to the device's web interface to cause the concentrator to temporarily stop processing traffic while the CPU utilization reaches 100% for approximately five minutes.

A remote user can query the device via SSH, FTP, or HTTP to obtain information about the device.  

A remote user can cause the concentrator to reload by connecting via PPTP with the 'No Encryption' option if the concentrator has encryption set.

A remote user can also submit a web form with large strings for the username and password to cause the device to reload.

A remote user with a VPN client can also submit a large string in response to the username prompt to cause the device to reload.

A remote user can send various malformed or large ISAKMP protocol packets to the device to cause the device to reload.

The system reportedly discloses some administrative passwords in clear text in the source of HTML pages provided to authenticated remote administrative users.  An authenticated remote administrative user may be able to view a password even if they don't have the appropriate level of administrative access.

A remote authenticated administrative user may be able to view the unencrypted certificate password in the HTML source of the Certificate Management HTML pages.

When configured in a certain manner, the VPN Concentrator may allow any protocol on any port to pass through the device.  If the XML filter configuration option is enabled on the public interface, a certain rule is added but with an incorrect protocol value.  The rule "HTTPS on Public Inbound (XML-Auto)(forward/in)" is reportedly added with a correct destination port of "443" and an incorrect protocol value of "ANY".  However, the device only checks destination ports when the protocol value is TCP or UDP, so this setting apparently lets any protocol through on any port.

A remote user can obtain certain limited information via the concentrator's web interface without providing valid authentication credentials.

A flaw was reported in the LAN-to-LAN IPSec tunneling feature.  The device does not verify that data from a LAN-to-LAN connection is originating from the correct network.

Affected platforms include the 3005, 3015, 3030, 3060, 3080, and the Cisco VPN 3002 Hardware Client.  The VPN Client software is not affected.  Also, the Cisco VPN 5000 series is not affected.

Cisco has assigned the following Cisco bug IDs to these vulnerabilities:  CSCdt56514, CSCdu15622, CSCdu35577, CSCdu82823, CSCdv66718, CSCdv88230, CSCdw22408, CSCdw50657, CSCdx07754, CSCdx24622, CSCdx24632, CSCdx39981, CSCdx54675 and CSCdy38035.
Impact': A remote user could cause the device to reload or to consume 100% of CPU resources for a temporary period of time.  If configured in a certain manner, a remote user could send unauthorized packets through the device.  A remote authenticated administrative user could view certain device and administrative passwords.  A rmeote user could obtain information about the device.
Solution:
Cisco has released fixed versions (3.5.5, or 3.6.1).  For a table listing the various upgrade releases, see the Vendor URL.

For instructions on how to upgrade, see:

http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/vpn/vpn3000/vpn3kco/vcoug/usr_3_0/admin.htm#xtocid2259937

Title: Cisco VPN 5000 Concentrator May Send Unencrypted Passwords Over the Network in a Certain Configuration
Description:
A vulnerability was reported in the Cisco VPN 5000 series concentrator when configured to use a RADIUS server to authenticate client connections and to use the Password Authentication Protocol (PAP) or the Challenge authentication challenge method.  A remote user sniffing the network connection may be able to obtain the user's unencrypted password.
It is reported that if validation fails the first time, the validation retry request sent to the RADIUS server includes the password in clear text.  This occurs if the device does not receive an Access-Accept packet from the RADIUS server within a specific time frame (for example, due to network or configuration problems).

Devices accepting clients using PAP authentication, aggressive mode (AM), or hybrid IKE Extended Authentication (XAUTH) mode, and validating against a RADIUS server, are reportedly affected.

Cisco notes that the older IntraPort series concentrator devices are also affected by this vulnerability. This series includes models IntraPort 2, IntraPort 2+, IntraPort Enterprise-2 and Enterprise-8, IntraPort Carrier-2, and Carrier-8.
Impact': The device may send an unencrypted password over the network to a RADIUS server.
Solution:
The vendor has released fixed software:

release 6.0.21.0003 (and later) and 5.2.23.0004 (and later)

The procedure to upgrade to the fixed software version is available at:

   http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/aggr/vpn5000/5000sw/conce60x/5000cfg/swinst.htm

A workaround involving using only CHAP for authentication is described in the Cisco advisory (see the Source Message or the Vendor URL).

Title: WatchGuard Firebox VPN Management Function Can Be Crashed By Remote Users Sending Malformed Packets
Description:
KPMG reported a denial of service vulnerability in WatchGuard Firebox in the Dynamic VPN Configuration Protocol (DVCP) service.  A remote user can cause the DVCP service to crash.
It is reported that a remote user can send specially crafted packets to the DVCP service on TCP port 4110 to cause WatchGuard's proprietary DVCP VPN management daemon to crash.  To trigger the vulnerability, the remote user must send between 1 and 400 packets of tab characters, followed by a CRLF. 

After the service has crashed, the device must be rebooted for the DVCP service to return to normal operations.
Impact': A remote user can cause the DVCP service to crash.  A reboot is required to return to normal operations.
Solution: The vendor has released a fixed version (6.x), available at WatchGuard's LiveSecurity website.  If you are not a subscriber to the LiveSecurity service, contact the vendor for assistance.

Title: (Vendor Issues Fix) Re: IBM 4758 Crypto Coprocessor Using Common Cryptographic Architecture (CCA) Software May Allow A Physically Local User to Extract 3DES Keys in Certain Situations
Description:
A vulnerability has been reported in an API used by the IBM 4758 Cryptographic Coprocessor.  A physically local user can extract encrypted keys from the device and can feasibly crack them offline.
It is reported that a physically local user can extract from an IBM 4758 running IBM's "Common Cryptographic Architecture" (CCA) support software (for ATM cash machines) all its DES and 3DES keys.  It is reported that the user must have the following to complete the task:

* about 20 minutes uninterrupted access to the device
* one person's ability to use the Combine_Key_Parts permission
* a standard off-the-shelf $995 FPGA evaluation board from Altera
* about two days of "cracking" time

The vulnerability is due to a key combination weakness in the CCA software that allows a user to create a replicate 3DES key (a 3DES key composed of two different halves) from a non-replicate 3DES key.

The report is available at:

http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~rnc1/descrack/
Impact': A physically local user with 'Combine_Key_Parts' permission can extract keys from the device.  Some offline brute force processing is required to decrypt the keys.
Solution:
Release 2.41 is available for download for all IBM 4758 Model 002 and 023 customers who use Windows 2000 or Windows NT  and for customers who use AIX with pSeries features #4958 and #4963.  It is available at:

http://www-3.ibm.com/security/cryptocards/html/ordersoftware.shtml

For more information about this release, see:

http://www-3.ibm.com/security/cryptocards/html/release241.shtml

Title: IBM 4758 Crypto Coprocessor Using Common Cryptographic Architecture (CCA) Software May Allow A Physically Local User to Extract 3DES Keys in Certain Situations

Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Series VPN Concentrators Allow Remote Users to Crash the Device
Description:
Cisco announced a vulnerability in their VPN 3000 series VPN concentrator that allows a remote user to crash the VPN device by sending a specially crafted IP packet.
If an IP packet with an invalid IP Option setting is transmitted to the VPN 3000 series concentrator on the same network segment (i.e., with no routers in between the source and the target VPN 3000), the VPN 3000 series concentrator may hang with 100% CPU Utilization.  The device must be reset via the console port in order to resume normal operation.

VPN models 3005, 3015, 3030, 3060, and 3080 are affected.  The vendor indicates that the VPN 5000 series concentrators are not vulnerable.

The vulnerability has been assigned Cisco bug id CSCds92460.
Impact': A remote user on the same network segment can craft a special IP packet to cause the VPN device to crash.
Solution: Cisco has released a fix and recommends upgrading to 2.5.2 (F).

Title: (CIAC Issues Bulletin) Re: Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator Series Will Reboot When the Management Port is Flooded With Data via the Network
Description:
Cisco announced a vulnerability in its VPN3000 Concentrator series products that allow a remote user to send a flood of data to the device's SSL or Telnet management port to cause the device to reboot.  The vendor notes that after rebooting, the device will function normally.
The SSL or telnet management session apparently does not disconnect after repeated failed attempts and the system keeps trying to interpret the data coming in on the management port.  As a result, data arriving at an excessive rate can flood the device's queues, causing a shortage of memory on the device and a corresponding reboot.

This vulnerability reportedly does not affect the VPN 5000 series concentrators or any other Cisco product.
Impact': A remote user can sending a flood of data to the SSL or telnet management ports to cause the VPN 3000 series concentrators to reboot. While reloading, the device cannot process any traffic.  If the device is repeatedly rebooted, a denial of service condition exists.
Solution: Obtain the vendor fix.   The new version will ensure that a SSL or telnet management session is terminated after three repeated failed attempts.

Title: (Additional Clarification About Security Impact) Re: The VPN Implementation on SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO Firewalls Uses Weak IKE Authentication Keys
Description:
A vulnerability has been discovered in the VPN implementation of SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO firewalls that uses short IKE pre-share key sizes.
A user writes to clarify the issue of security in relation to 48 byte IKE pre-shared keys:

"The shared secret is used for the authentication of the keying material; the length constraints discussed do not affect overall security of the system.  The shared secret is used in as a 'key' in a HMAC (see rfc 2104).  Keys longer than 64 bytes (the block size of sha1 and md5) are hashed first to generate a value < 64 bytes.  The only issue with security strength is that the key should be be longer than the length of the hash output (20 bytes for sha1, 16 bytes for md5)."

Quoting from rfc 2104:

   The key for HMAC can be of any length (keys longer than B bytes are
   first hashed using H).  However, less than L bytes is strongly
   discouraged as it would decrease the security strength of the
   function.  Keys longer than L bytes are acceptable but the extra
   length would not significantly increase the function strength. (A
   longer key may be advisable if the randomness of the key is
   considered weak.)

Although the keystreams are dependant on the shared secret, the
dependancy is as discussed above, so there really is no problem with
security.  The exact relationships can be found in rfc 2409, btw."
Impact': VPN sessions that are created using short IKE pre-shared keys could be decrypted, even if long session keys are used.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the vendor is working on a firmware fix.

Title: Cisco VPN 3000 Concentrator Series Will Reboot When the Management Port is Flooded With Data via the Network
Description:
Cisco announced a vulnerability in its VPN3000 Concentrator series products that allow a remote user to send a flood of data to the device's SSL or Telnet management port to cause the device to reboot.  The vendor notes that after rebooting, the device will function normally.
The SSL or telnet management session apparently does not disconnect after repeated failed attempts and the system keeps trying to interpret the data coming in on the management port.  As a result, data arriving at an excessive rate can flood the device's queues, causing a shortage of memory on the device and a corresponding reboot.

This vulnerability reportedly does not affect the VPN 5000 series concentrators or any other Cisco product.
Impact': A remote user can sending a flood of data to the SSL or telnet management ports to cause the VPN 3000 series concentrators to reboot. While reloading, the device cannot process any traffic.  If the device is repeatedly rebooted, a denial of service condition exists.
Solution: Obtain the vendor fix.   The new version will ensure that a SSL or telnet management session is terminated after three repeated failed attempts.

Title: (Technical Clarifications) Re: The VPN Implementation on SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO Firewalls Uses Weak IKE Authentication Keys
Description:
A vulnerability has been discovered in the VPN implementation of SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO firewalls that uses short IKE pre-share key sizes.
A user writes to clarify that the pre-shared IKE key is used only for authentication, not to encrypt data.  The user notes that "it's deeply unclear as to whether even very VERY weak pre-shared keys materially affect the entropy in the resultant keying material."
Impact': The impact of this vulnerability may be minimal, according to a user (see the source message).
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the vendor is working on a firmware fix.

Title: The VPN Implementation on SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO Firewalls Uses Weak IKE Authentication Keys
Description:
A vulnerability has been discovered in the VPN implementation of SonicWALL's Tele2 and SOHO firewalls that uses short IKE pre-share key sizes.
When using these products in a gateway-to-gateway VPN configuration using IPSec with IKE pre-shared keys, the IKE pre-shared keys are limited to 48 bytes.

The vendor has confirmed the vulnerability.
Impact': VPN sessions that are created using short IKE pre-shared keys could be decrypted, even if long session keys are used.
Solution: No solution was available at the time of this entry.  However, the vendor is working on a firmware fix.

Title: Watchguard Firebox II VPN Feature (PPTP) Can Be Remotely Crashed
Version(s): Policy manager version 4.50-B1780, Watchguard product version 4.50-612, possibly previous versions as well
Description:
It is reportedly possible to remotely cause the Watchguard PPTP daemon to crash by sending malformed PPTP packets to the firewall/VPN.  After the crash, a reboot is required to restore PPTP functionality to the Watchguard device.
Defcom Labs reports that connecting to the PPTP port with telnet approximately 12 times and then disconnecting causes the PPTP daemon to terminate.
Impact': When the PPTP daemon crashes, all connected users will be disconnected and no new connections will be acceppted.  The device must be rebooted before the PPTP service will function properly.
Solution: Obtain the patch from the vendor (requires a service contract).
